case_name: Associated Cement Companies Limited v. Their Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 404 of 1958 filed by Associated Cement Companies Limited.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 404 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the decision dated March 10, 1958,

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from decision dated March 10, 1958 of Industrial Tribunal, Rajkot in Adjudication Case No. 67 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 404 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the decision dated March 10, 1958, of the Industrial Tribunal, Rajkot, in Adjudication Case No. 67 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 3, 1960 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. March, 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-Can a registered trade union representing a minority of workmen governed by an award give notice to the other party intimating its intention to terminate the award under S. 19(6) of the Industrial Disputes Act XIV of 1947 hereinafter called the Act ?

facts.text: Associated Cement Companies Limited is the appellant and owns cement factories including Porbandar Cement Works in Saurashtra.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal has been brought before this Court by the Associated Cement Companies Limited hereinafter called the appellant against their workman hereinafter called the respondents , and it arises from an industrial dispute between them which was referred for adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal for the State of Saurashtra by the Saurashtra Government under s. 10(1) of the Act.

facts.text: Industrial dispute between appellant and respondents referred to Industrial Tribunal, Saurashtra under s.10(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal has been brought before this Court by the Associated Cement Companies Limited hereinafter called the appellant against their workman hereinafter called the respondents , and it arises from an industrial dispute between them which was referred for adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal for the State of Saurashtra by the Saurashtra Government under s. 10(1) of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant raised four preliminary objections to competence of reference, rejected by tribunal on March 10, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: When the tribunal began its proceedings the appellant raised four preliminary objections against the competence of the reference itself. The tribunal heard parties on these preliminary objections, and by its interlocutory judgment delivered on March 10, 1958, it has found against the appellant on all the points.

facts.text: Appellant contends reference incompetent because award not terminated under s.19(6) by minority union Cement Kamdar Mandal.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the four points urged by the appellant as preliminary objections we are concerned with only one in the present appeal, and that relates to the incompetence of the reference on the ground that the award in question by which the parties were bound has not been duly terminated under s. 19(6) of the Act inasmuch as the union which purported to terminate the said award represents only a minority of workmen bound by it.

facts.text: Industrial dispute arose in 1949, referred on March 22, 1949, award made September 13, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: An industrial dispute arose between the appellant and the respondents in 1949 and it was referred for adjudication to the industrial tribunal on March 22, 1949. This reference ended in an award made on September 13, 1949.

facts.text: Appellant terminated the 1949 award.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the said award was terminated by the appellant and on disputes arising between it and the respondents another reference was made to the same tribunal for adjudication of the said disputes.

facts.text: Second award made on July 24, 1951, continuing earlier award with modifications.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the said award was terminated by the appellant and on disputes arising between it and the respondents another reference was made to the same tribunal for adjudication of the said disputes. A second award was made on July 24, 1951, by which the earlier award with slight modifications was ordered to continue in operation.

facts.text: Registration of Kamdar Mandal, Cement Works, Porbandar cancelled on July 2, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In the proceedings in respect of both the references the appellants workmen were represented by their Union called Kamdar Mandal, Cement Works, Porbandar. It appears that the registration of the said union was cancelled on July 2,1954,

facts.text: Cement Kamdar Mandal registered on July 7, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: and that led to the formation of two unions of the appellants workmen, the Cement Kamdar Mandal which was registered on July 7, 1954, and the Cement Employees Union which was registered on September 18, 1954.

facts.text: Cement Employees Union registered on September 18, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: and that led to the formation of two unions of the appellants workmen, the Cement Kamdar Mandal which was registered on July 7, 1954, and the Cement Employees Union which was registered on September 18, 1954.

facts.text: Cement Kamdar Mandal gave notice on September 23, 1954 to terminate 1949 award.

anchor.surface_text: The Cement Kamdar Mandal gave notice to the appellants manager on September 23, 1954, purporting to terminate the first award pronounced on September 13, 1949, at the expiration of two months notice from the date of the said communication.

facts.text: Cement Kamdar Mandal letter on December 20, 1954 to terminate 1951 award.

anchor.surface_text: By another letter written on December 20,1954, the same union purported to terminate the second award pronounced on July 24, 1951, in a similar manner.

facts.text: Cement Kamdar Mandal presented fresh demands on November 22, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On November 22, 1954, the said Mandal presented fresh demands most of which were covered by the two previous awards.

facts.text: Conciliation efforts failed, Saurashtra Government referred demands under s.10(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The said demands were referred to the Conciliation Officer for conciliation but the efforts at conciliation failed., and on receiving a failure report from the officer the Saurashtra Government made the present reference purporting to exercise its jurisdiction under s. 10(1)(c) of the Act.

facts.text: Cement Employees Union represents majority of workmen, raised disputes not referred.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile it appears that the Cement Employees Union, which represents the majority of the appellants workmen at Porbandar, instead of giving notice of termination under s. 19(6) raised disputes with the appellant and the same were referred to the Conciliation Officer.

facts.text: Cement Employees Union supports demands of Cement Kamdar Mandal.

anchor.surface_text: In the present proceedings this Union has been impleaded and it has supported the demands made by the Cement Kamdar Mandal in other words, notwithstanding the rivalry between the two Unions, the demands made by the minority union were supported by the majority union,

facts.text: Tribunal assumed Cement Kamdar Mandal is minority union and rejected appellant's objection.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal has dealt with the point of law raised by the appellant under s. 19(6) on the assumption that the Cement Kamdar Mandal which purported to terminate the awards under the said section represents the minority of the workmen employed at Porbandar,

facts.text: Court holds minority union can give notice under s.19(6) if acting collectively.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that, on a fair- and reasonable construction of s. 19(6) the true position is that, though the expression any party bound by the award refers to all workmen bound by the award, notice to terminate the said award can be given not by an individual workman but by a group of workmen acting collectively either through their union or otherwise,

facts.text: Cement Kamdar Mandal is a registered trade union.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-Can a registered trade union representing a minority of workmen governed by an award give notice to the other party intimating its intention to terminate the award under S. 19(6) of the Industrial Disputes Act XIV of 1947 hereinafter called the Act ?
terminate the award under S. 19 6  of the Industrial Disputes Act XIV of 1947  hereinafter called the Act ? That is the short question which arises for decision in the present appeal.

concepts.interpretation: though the expression any party bound by the award refers to all workmen bound by the award, notice to terminate the said award can be given not by an individual workman but by a group of workmen acting collectively either through their union or otherwise, and it is not necessary that such a group or the union through which it acts should represent the majority of workmen bound by the award.

arguments.claim: The reference is incompetent because the award has not been duly terminated under s.19(6) of the Act as the notice was given by a minority union.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the four points urged by the appellant as preliminary objections we are concerned with only one in the present appeal, and that relates to the incompetence of the reference on the ground that the award in question by which the parties were bound has not been duly terminated under s. 19(6) of the Act inasmuch as the union which purported to terminate the said award represents only a minority of workmen bound by it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he companyclusion that it is open to a minority of workmen or a minority union to terminate the award by which they, along with other employees, are b

arguments.court_reasoning: Minority group or union acting collectively can give notice under s.19(6); majority not required.

arguments.claim: s.19(6) should be construed to preclude minority from terminating award to prevent disturbance to smooth working and creation of industrial disputes.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General has urged before us that we should construe s. 19(6) so as to preclude a minority of workmen bound by the award from disturbing the smooth working of the award and thereby creating an industrial dispute. When an award is made it binds the parties for the statutory period under s. 19(3)

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e to claim a majority of members on their rolls, and in their present stage of Organization in very few cases would a majority of workmen be able to m

arguments.court_reasoning: Imposing majority requirement would prejudice employees as trade unions do not cover majority; termination would be difficult.

arguments.claim: Rule 83 framed under s.38 supports construction that only majority can terminate award.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that when this question was argued before the tribunal the appellant strongly relied on rule 83 framed by the Government of Bombay under s. 38 of the Act and it was urged that the said rule is consistent

court_response_anchor.surface_text: made at their instance ? The anomaly to which the learned Attorney-General refers has numberpractical significance. If the majority of workmen bound

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule was not in force at the relevant time and thus not applicable.

arguments.claim: Cement Kamdar Mandal validly terminated the awards under s.19(6) despite being minority union.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal has dealt with the point of law raised by the appellant under s. 19(6) on the assumption that the Cement Kamdar Mandal which purported to terminate the awards under the said section represents the minority of the workmen employed at Porbandar,

arguments.court_reasoning: Court sees no reason to differ from tribunal's view.

arguments.claim: 'Any party bound by the award' literally includes even a single employee able to terminate.

anchor.surface_text: Literally construed, any party bound by the award may mean even a single employee who is bound by the award, and on this literal construction even one dissatisfied employee may be entitled to give notice terminating the award.

arguments.claim: 'Any party bound by the award' cannot include an individual workman; requires group acting collectively.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to this aspect of the matter it would be difficult to hold that any party bound by the award can include an individual workman, though speaking literally he is a party bound by the award.

arguments.claim: Expression 'any party bound by the award' does not require majority union or group.

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the question as to whether the expression any party bound by the award must mean a union representing the majority of the workmen bound by it or a group of workmen constituting such majority acting otherwise than through the union.

arguments.claim: Minority group or union can terminate award consistent with ability to raise industrial dispute under s.10.

anchor.surface_text: There is another aspect of the question which is also relevant and which, in our opinion, is against the construction suggested by the appellant. We have already noticed that an industrial dispute can be raised by a group of workmen or by a union even though neither of them represent the majority of the workmen concerned

arguments.claim: True position under s.19(6): notice by group of workmen acting collectively through union or otherwise, not necessarily majority.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that, on a fair and reasonable construction of s. 19(6) the true position is that, though the expression any party bound by the award refers to all workmen bound by the award, notice to terminate the said award can be given not by an individual workman but by a group of workmen acting collectively either through their union or otherwise, and it is not necessary that such a group or the union through which it acts should represent the majority of workmen bound by the award.

arguments.claim: Expression does not include individual workman.

anchor.surface_text: We ought to add that this position is fairly conceded by Mr. Sharma for the respondents.

arguments.court_reasoning: Consistent with industrial adjudication principles and precedents.

holdings.text: on a fair and reasonable construction of s. 19(6) the true position is that, though the expression any party bound by the award refers to all workmen bound by the award, notice to terminate the said award can be given not by an individual workman but by a group of workmen acting collectively either through their union or otherwise, and it is not necessary that such a group or the union through which it acts should represent the majority of workmen bound by the award

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that, on a fair- and reasonable construction of s. 19(6) the true position is that, though the expression any party bound by the award refers to all workmen bound by the award, notice to terminate the said award can be given not by an individual workman but by a group of workmen acting collectively either through their union or otherwise,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fair and reasonable construction of s.19(6) in light of ss.18, 2(k); collective bargaining essence; minority can raise disputes under s.10; precedents on industrial disputes; policy against majority requirement prejudicing employees

holdings.text: the said expression cannot include an individual workman

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to this aspect of the matter it would be difficult to hold that any party bound by the award can include an individual workman, though speaking literally he is a party bound by the award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal includes individual rejected; industrial disputes require union sponsorship or group support per s.2(k) and precedents; conceded by respondents

holdings.text: the effect of s. 18 is that an award properly made by an industrial tribunal governs the employer and all those who represent him under s. 18(c) and the employees who are parties to the dispute and all those who are included in s. 18(b) and (d)

anchor.surface_text: in other words, the effect of s. 18 is that an award properly made by an industrial tribunal governs the employer and all those who represent him under s. 18 c  and the employees who are parties to the dispute and all those who are included in s. 18 b  and  d .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of s.18 clauses specifying binding effect on wide class beyond disputants

holdings.text: it is open to a minority of workmen or a minority union to terminate the award by which they, along with other employees, are bound just as much as it is open to them to raise an industrial dispute under the Act

anchor.surface_text: We have already noticed that an industrial dispute can be raised by a group of workmen or by a union even though neither of them represent the majority of the workmen concerned

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistency with s.10 allowing minority disputes; logic and fairplay; avoids prejudice to employees lacking majority unions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conceded factually not in force at time of notice

precedents.citation: The Central Provinces Trans- port Services Limited v. Raghunath Gopal Patwardhan  1 1956 S.C.R. 956

anchor.surface_text: In The Central Provinces Trans- port Services Limited v. Raghunath Gopal Patwardhan  1  this Court has observed that the preponderance of judicial opinion is clearly in favour of the view that an individual dispute cannot per se be an industrial dispute but may become one if taken up by a  1

precedents.case_name: Central Provinces Transport Services Limited v Raghunath Gopal Patwardhan
precedents.cited_proposition: an individual dispute cannot per se be an industrial dispute but may become one if taken up by a trade union or a number of persons

precedents.citation: The Newspapers Limited v. The State Industrial Tribunal, U.  1 1957 S.C.R 754

anchor.surface_text: These observations have been cited with approval by this Court in the case of The Newspapers Limited v. The State Industrial Tribunal, U.  1  1957 S.C.R 754.
